ERT are trained for a response In OSHA Confined space, hazardous materials response, and take the state level basic firefighter course. 

The Emergency Response Team (ERT) practices drills each quarter to maintain response skill and proficiencies 

COMMUNICATIONS DISPATCHERS Communications dispatchers are trained to manage the communications hub in plant security during emergency situations.

 6. PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY: Clinton Laboratories is committed to continuous safety improvement and risk reduction. A system to conduct Process Hazard Reviews is in place. The system will assure Process Hazard Reviews are conducted for each of the appropriate processes at Clinton Laboratories. 

The mechanical systems are routinely tested to ensure proper operation and performance. Any problems found are corrected and opportunities for improvement are noted and evaluated. 

Plans to improve the mitigation of chlorine releases are in place. At a minimum, Clinton Labs will evaluate the benefits of installing area detectors around all chlorine process locations. 

Drills are also conducted to practice and improve the procedures for responding to emergencies

management. The on-site emergency response capabilities include full time emergency response teams (described below), fire and spill response equipment, rescue apparatus, ambulance service, and clinic. Regular drills test readiness and help employees practice responses to alarms and incidents. 

EMERGENCY RESPONSE TEAMS Site emergency response team members participate in frequent training conducted both internally and externally. In an emergency situation, a member of the plant security staff fulfills the incident commander role. The Incident Commander directs all field response activities and makes regular reports to the management support team as the incident proceeds. The Incident Commander and Incident Team Leaders direct the specific tactical actions of the emergency response teams, described below. Approximately 70 employees who hold full time jobs elsewhere on the site make up the emergency response teams. Most of the employees are cross-trained on more than one team. A brief description of the teams follows. 

FIRE BRIGADE/HAZARDOUS MATERIAL (HAZMAT) TEAM This is a combined team of both fire fighting and hazardous material spill response. The fire brigade is a structural fire fighting organization trained to respond to industrial fires and are trained to the Indiana state mandatory level for fire fighters. The Haz Mat responders are trained to the OSHA Technician level and are aware of the various chemical hazards on site. Hazardous material response includes responding to hazardous spills or vapor releases. Responders are trained to use proper equipment and techniques to stabilize a hazardous area and rescue employees who may need help. Team undergoes rigorous training in fire fighting and/or hazmat response. 

CONFINED SPACE RESCUE TEAM This group specializes in rescue from tanks, pits and other confined areas. They are trained to use ropes and mechanical rescue techniques. 

FIRST RESPONDERS Emergency services staffs two FF/EMT's and state instruc

acture and package flea and tick prevention products, and a large packaging facility for US distribution of Pet Animal products manufactured at other Elanco facilities.
The following regulated substances are handled at Clinton Laboratories in quantities above the threshold quantities established under the RMP regulations: 

TOXICS: anhydrous ammonia up to 60,000 lb and 1-ton chlorine cylinders (up to 40,000 lb) storage and operation at various locations onsite 

FLAMMABLES - None 

3. THE GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND THE SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS: Clinton Laboratories is subject to Indiana OSHA's Process Safety Management requirements, as well as other Indiana OSHA requirements. The facility is also subject to regulation by other agencies, including the Indiana Department of Environmental Management and the United States Environmental Protection Agency. 

Specific prevention programs include conducting pre-startup and design hazard assessments, proactive maintenance programs, routine vessel inspections, emergency response training, safe to work programs, employee and contractor safety programs, and accident investigation programs. 

4. FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY: Clinton Laboratories keeps records for all significant accidental chemical releases that occur at our facility. In the five-year period, through May 2022, Clinton Laboratories has had no accidents as defined in the 40 CFR 68.42. 

5. THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM: EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT AT CLINTON LABORATORIES The Clinton Laboratories Incident Management System is comprehensive. It includes elements such as: site emergency response plan, employee protective actions, the emergency management organization, and implementation of a response, post incident procedures and building specific pre-emergency plans. The plan is executed through a cooperative effort between the site's management support team, full time emergency response teams, local law enforcement, and local emergency

ratories plays an active role in its Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC). A primary goal of the LEPC is to protect local citizens by developing and maintaining a coordinated emergency response plan and working with industry to minimize the impacts of chemical hazards. Through the LEPC, citizens can obtain information about hazardous substances handled at local facilities and about emergency planning efforts designed to successfully cope with accidents if they occur. The LEPC maintains a coordinated emergency response plan for the community detailing operational procedures to be followed in the event of an accident involving hazardous materials. The plan is available for public inspection. 

Clinton Laboratories actively supports local community outreach efforts through Community Advisory Panels and neighbor groups. These panels provide useful feedback from the community and advise Elanco on community issues. Site management and employees are committed to process safety and actively seek opportunities for continuous improvement. 

2. THE STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED: Clinton Laboratories is divided into three main functional areas. Farm Animal Health manufacturing, on the south end of the plant, manufactures feed additives and other animal health products. Manufacturing activities include fermentation, recovery, finishing, and packaging products onsite for worldwide delivery to customers. The second functional area, site services, is located primarily in the center of the plant, with other buildings throughout the plant. Services provided include: steam, water, heat transfer media, electricity, and maintenance support. The services area provides support for Animal Health areas. The facility has a Title V operating permit under the Clean Air Act. The third functional area, Pet Animal Health manufacturing, primarily on the north of the plant, manufactures and packages pet animal health products. There are small batch processes that manuf

Elanco is a world leader in developing products and services that enhance animal health, wellness and performance. Elanco manufactures animal health products at its Clinton Laboratories facility (Clinton Laboratories). Clinton Laboratories is located approximately five miles north of Clinton, Indiana. Operations at Clinton Laboratories began in June of 1970. Clinton Laboratories is located on a 700-acre site. The plant itself includes over 60 buildings on 200 acres. This document provides a brief overview of the comprehensive risk management activities that Clinton Laboratories has designed and implemented, including: 

1. Accidental release prevention and emergency response policies 

2. The stationary source and regulated substances handled 

3. The general accidental release prevention program and the specific prevention steps 

4. Five-year accident history 

5. The emergency response program 

6. Planned changes to improve safety 

1. ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES: Clinton Laboratories is committed to operating and maintaining all processes in a safe and responsible manner. This is especially important for those processes using hazardous chemicals. Clinton Laboratories has numerous systems in place to manage these chemicals. Elanco uses a combination of accidental release prevention programs and emergency response planning programs to ensure the safety of employees and the public as well as protection of the environment. Clinton Laboratories accidental release prevention programs and contingency planning efforts help effectively manage the hazards that are posed to employees, the public, and the environment by the use of these chemicals. 
Clinton Laboratories has a Plant Emergency Response Plan that contains procedures on how to handle emergencies that occur. The emergency response plan includes procedures for notification of local authorities and notification of any potentially affected neighbors.
